stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on two parallel tasks: finishing a total rewrite of Mario 64’s sound engine and rough-blocking the massive overworld for Return to Yoshi’s Island. He tests the new audio code (still buggy), discusses its performance gains, and live-models terrain, villages, and decorative elements while chatting about design philosophy and release strategy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rewrote the entire Mario 64 sound engine; it now runs ~80 % faster, uses a quarter of the code, needs less memory, and doubles polyphony from 16 to 32 notes.
development_findings.quote: The sound engine is now around 80 % faster than vanilla, the code is a quarter of the size, we need much less memory, and we support 32 notes instead of 16.

development_findings.summary: Remaining audio work involves fixing red-coin synth-wave glitches and implementing a more robust DMA/allocation system; once done they can freely add new sound effects.
development_findings.quote: Ideally, once I'm done with it, it will allow us to add a lot more sound effects… I still got a little bit of sound stuff to do.

development_findings.summary: The new overworld will be the largest level Kaze has ever built, planned for roughly 30 stars and multiple sub-areas (main Yoshi Village, Mountain Yoshi Village, Bowser entrance, Boshi’s target practice, tree-houses, a flower farm, wool warehouse, small boats, and a snow-peak castle).
Design goal: after the final boss the game world remains in its ‘saved’ state so players can freely explore post-game instead of being reset to pre-ending status.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to save the world and then be like, yep, this is the world now. You saved it. Look at that.

development_findings.summary: Overworld music system will feature at least 12 unique tracks that cross-fade as the player moves between areas; composer 0VALT is supplying the pieces.
development_findings.quote: This is just one of like 15 songs… The song is going to fade whenever you walk to a different area.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans full custom textures for legal safety; many already exist, and additional texture artists may be hired later to ensure every asset is original.
development_findings.quote: If I want this to all be legal, I would technically need custom textures for everything… I'll get a bunch of texture artists to help with that.

development_findings.summary: Upcoming YouTube video and in-game work involve a new RNG function that mixes real-world entropy sources (e.g., temperature) to improve randomness on N64.
development_findings.quote: The video is about finding a new RNG algorithm that uses real-world entropy as well.

development_findings.summary: Texture workflow shown live: multi-texture combiners, UV-cleanup, and per-pixel alpha to vary sand graininess—illustrating the team’s optimization of N64 rendering limits.
No further public demos are planned; next public build will be the full game.
development_findings.quote: I don't think there will be another demo. The next release will be the full game.

development_findings.summary: Release date will be chosen to avoid overlap with major Nintendo announcements to reduce legal risk; Kaze refuses to give even a tentative window.
development_findings.quote: I can't release this around the same time as Nintendo releases anything… If I release this I have to find a period of time where Nintendo is not dropping any big announcement.

context_findings.summary: Kaze lives in Canada after moving from Europe in 2021 to be with Zeina; permanent residency is secured and citizenship test is in two months.
context_findings.quote: I moved to Canada in November 2021… in two months I can take the citizenship test and then I will be a Canadian citizen.

context_findings.summary: He balances a normal programming day-job, video sponsorships (two days per video), and ROM-hack development by minimizing passive free-time use.
context_findings.quote: Honestly, it's not that hard to find time for this stuff… you waste most of your free time.

context_findings.summary: Financial motivation influences the frequency of sponsored YouTube videos; Kaze openly seeks sponsorships to fund personal and project expenses.
context_findings.quote: I find sponsors and sponsors make videos for us and will pay you a lot of money, so I'm like, okay, I'll make the video. I want the money.

context_findings.summary: Expresses frustration with community projects (Hackamari64) that diverge from his standards, revealing competitive pride and protective attitude toward his code.
context_findings.quote: At first I thought the Hackamari64 project was cool, but I became a hater over time because they kept making really weird decisions.

context_findings.summary: Shows general design philosophy: optimize because hardware limits feel restrictive, but optimization became a public branding accidentally.
context_findings.quote: Originally I didn't even make this mod for the optimization… it just kind of happened because I felt too limited by the hardware.

biobak.summary: Responsible for most custom textures; several entire levels still awaiting his rework.
biobak.quote: There are still so many levels for Biobak to rework.

biobak.summary: Supplied Kaze with a Blender UV-straightening plugin, improving texture workflow.

zeina.summary: Zeina is Kaze’s spouse and animator; her relationship prompted his relocation to Canada.

key_stories.title: Reinventing the N64 Sound Engine
key_stories.summary: Frustrated by memory limits and note polyphony, Kaze decided to scrap Nintendo’s original audio driver and build a new one from scratch. Over the past week he finished most of the rewrite and demonstrated it live despite lingering red-coin glitches.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla engine was heavy, capped at 16 notes, and resisted additional SFX.
key_stories.process: Reverse-engineered original code, rewrote core in C/assembly, tested with placeholder music, debugged synth-wave issues.
key_stories.outcome: 80 % speed gain, 32-note polyphony, quarter code size, groundwork for richer music and sound effects.
key_stories.key_quote: The sound engine is now around 80 % faster… and we support 32 notes instead of 16.

key_stories.title: Filling the Empty Overworld
key_stories.summary: Early overworld mock-ups felt vast and barren. During the stream Kaze scaled terrain, inserted mountain ranges, and plotted themed sub-areas (villages, Bowser gateway, wool warehouse) to create density without clutter.
key_stories.challenge: Large spaces between Yoshi Village and Bowser zone felt lifeless.
key_stories.process: Live Blender editing: rearranged cliffs, added tree hammocks, carved mountains, brainstormed landmarks, iteratively UV-mapped textures.
key_stories.outcome: A more compact yet varied hub planned for ~30 stars, with clear thematic districts.
key_stories.key_quote: This still feels big and flat… maybe it would be better if I actually had some proper mountain region here.

key_stories.title: Relocating for Love and Work
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Zeina began talking in 2020, met in person, and within roughly a year he moved from Europe to Canada, opting for marriage and permanent residency rather than long-distance.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining a long-distance relationship while juggling development and day job.
key_stories.process: Zeina visited Germany; Kaze disliked travel, so he relocated permanently, secured residency, and is nearing citizenship.
key_stories.outcome: Stable personal life in Canada, enabling ongoing collaboration on the hack.
key_stories.key_quote: I moved to Canada in November 2021… I’m completely reckless, I just do what I feel like.
